fields.description: I saw SRCTREE-2873 and was wondering if this can be also added to Windows version of SourceTree (or I simply don't know how to do it)?
fields.summary: Sorting of local repos in the Repository Broswer

fields.description:
When you right click on a revision in the change log you receive a dialog as follows

https://www.screencast.com/t/7yEUqGcJMHEr
!https://www.screencast.com/t/7yEUqGcJMHEr!

External Diff launches an external tool to display the differences between the selected revision and the previous revision.  Add an additional entry called "Diff To Local" to launch an external tool to display the differences between the selected revision and the local file.

This would be handy for cherry picking changes within a file from another revision or branch into the local file.

This is similar to the feature offered in TortoiseHg Workbench..

https://www.screencast.com/t/di4tTFcXN
!https://www.screencast.com/t/di4tTFcXN!

The Diff to Parent selection is the equivalent of Source Tree's External Diff menu selection.
fields.summary: Add "Diff To Local" selection to the log revision context menu

fields.description:
Despite updating via:

Repository -> Refresh Remote Status

the deleted branches are furthermore shown in Sourcetree Enterprise

A fresh clone does not show this branches.
fields.summary: Sourcetree Enterprise shows deleted feature branches from Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
Creating git branches that use a comma ',' character cause UI and other issues.

Reproduction steps:
 # Create a branch using a comma ',' in it's name
 # Switch to another branch
 # Attempt to switch back to the branch with a comma in it's name using the Graph view under the 'Log / View History' tab.  Note that the branch name in this area is truncated at the comma and that attempted checkouts from here fail.
 # Attempt to switch back to the branch using the Branches list.  Note that the branch name is complete and not truncated at the comma and that the checkout works as intended.
fields.summary: Issue with branches with commas in their name

fields.description:
Reproduction Steps:
 # Create a branch using a comma ',' character in it's name
 # Switch to another branch
 # Attempt to switch back to the branch with a comma in it's name using the Graph view under the 'Log / View History' tab.  Notethat the branch name in this area is truncated at the comma and that attempted checkouts from here fail.
 # Attempt to switch back to the rbanch using the Branches list.  Note that the branch name is complete and not truncated at the comma and that the checkout works as intended.
fields.summary: Issue with branches with commas in their name

fields.description: Diff of minified code shows weird. It's not useful, and it looks broken.
fields.summary: Diff of minified code shows weird

fields.description:
When using the windows credential manager with a space in my windows username I am currently unable to connect to my VSTS repo, since sourcetree fails with an error:

 
{code:java}
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false --no-optional-locks -c credential.helper= -c "credential.helper=C:/Users/Rune Jensen/AppData/Local/Atlassian/SourceTree/git_extras/git-credential-manager.exe" fetch origin
C:/Users/Rune Jensen/AppData/Local/Atlassian/SourceTree/git_extras/git-credential-manager.exe get: C:/Users/Rune: No such file or directory
C:/Users/Rune Jensen/AppData/Local/Atlassian/SourceTree/git_extras/git-credential-manager.exe erase: C:/Users/Rune: No such file or directory
fatal: Authentication failed for '[REDACTED]'
Completed with errors, see above.{code}
fields.summary: Using credential manager with space in windows username fails

fields.description:
Occasionally, when switching to the Log view, I will find that a commit somewhere far down the list (my repo presently has 560 commits) has been multiselected in addition to the latest commit. This causes SourceTree to show a diff view between that commit and my working copy. For some reason, this multiselect cannot be cleared by just clicking on another commit with no modifier keys; I have to scroll down to the commit that was inappropriately selected, and only then can I clear the selection.

I've been able to reproduce consistently with these steps:
 # Make changes to two files.
 # Switch to File Status view.
 # Separately stage and commit each file's change.
 # Switch back to Log view by clicking master branch on left.
 # Mixed reset to first commit.
 # Stash.
 # Mixed reset to first commit's parent.
 # Select Working Copy on left.
 # Stage and commit file.
 # Apply the stash from the left pane.
 # Switch to log view by clicking master on the left.

Another entry will be inappropriately selected at this point. It seems to always be about halfway down the list, which I suspect is an artifact of the number of commits I have; SourceTree will sometimes say it's loading 300 commits, which would put it at about the halfway mark. When the repo was smaller, I remember seeing this issue, but then the inappropriately selected commit was near the end.
fields.summary: Log view spuriously selects commit in middle of scroll range
Custom repository tabs names reverting to original Names

fields.description:
Sourcetree won't stop loading very oftenly. With this problem, I oftenly can't see the changes in a file. In other cases, it's excessively distracting, in some semi-rare cases it even causes me to mis-click and click something else because the UI decides to shove things around while loading.

 

This could mean a (semi-)permanent loader in:

1) Log/Hostory tab, lower-right pane. File content is not displayed, selecting another file does nothing. Loading loading loading until the end of time.

2) Same thing on the file status tab on the right pane.

3) Same thing in the Push dialog in the lower-right pane.

4) In the left pane, and progress bar style loader at the very top of the left pane. Appears to stop and restart loading dozens of times.

5) In the left pane, when opening the shelves dropdown, a spinning loader will appear and dissappear countless times. If there are shelves, they too will phase in and out of existence many times.

 

What is it actually loading, and why won't it stop?

Can you please fix this once and for all please?

 

Please note that this problem has now existed for at least half a year. Tried every update ever. How does this get pas QA? Do they not test if loading ever finishes?
fields.summary: Won't stop loading

fields.description:
Shelve is horribly HORRIBLY broken.

It took me a goddamn hour to fix my repo after shelving a change. Here's what I did:

 

1) Have some changes in the working dir.

2) Realize I'm on the wrong branch

3) Switch to default branch

4) Get an erro saying that I have uncomitted changed. So what?? Switch the goddamn branch!!

5) Give up and shelve my changes

6) Switch to default branch

7) Make the branch I'm suposed to commit in

8) Switch to it

9) Unshelve my changes

10) This produces some conflicts

11) Solve the conflicts

12) Commit

13) Error: unshelve already in progress. WTF? Just let me commit my goddamn code!! SourceTree, if you get this error, solve it yourself. Don't tell me to execute some command.

14) Try the suggestion (hg unshelve –continue). Doesn't work. The "unshelve" command doesn't exist. So don't bloody suggest it then, FFS!!

15) I also can't update to a previous commit. Same error.

16) Ohh, I can strip to a previous commit. But any path will lead to the same error again.

17) Delete the shelve and try yet again. Same error. An unshelve is already in progress... with 0 shelves existing. Absolutely bloody brilliant this.

18) Try the same thing from WLS. Doesn't work. Unshelve can be installed from there, but it says it's the wrong version. I'm done with this now. I'm going to resort to unreasonable force.

19) Go into my repo\.hg, and DELETE every file that has the word "shelve" in the name.

20) Fixed. FINALLY.

 

Please, Atlassian, this is utterly ridiculous. It shouldn't be so goddamn hard to switch branches while already having some changes. Test those features, and test them well please.

I almost lost my work a few times. That's quite the opposite of SourceTree's purpose, innit. Good thing I created a patch file.

 

Btw, I'm on 2.4.8.0, but this Jira says that version doesn't exist. It sure does.
fields.summary: Shelve doesn't work

fields.description:
SourceTree does not load multiple SSH keys after the restart.

If they were added by "Tools->Add SSH Key..." everything works fine until an application restart. Issues are with an openssh_add.cmd file, ssh-add %* command does not parse ";" separated string.

Changing openssh_add.cmd to:

@echo off
echo.
echo SourceTree is loading your SSH key into the agent for authentication
echo Please enter your passphrase if prompted to do so
echo.
set x=%*
For %%_ In (%x%) DO (
ssh-add %%_
)

 

Have fixed this issue.
fields.summary: Multiple SSH Keys does not load after the restart

fields.description:
When starting from shortcut in windows start menu SourceTree shows white-on-blue logo splash screen for about a minute and then crashes.

!https://i.imgur.com/hhqwa00.png!

Is there a way I can provide you with more details like crash dumps or logs?

Is it safe to uninstall SourceTree and install it again without losing configuration?
fields.summary: Crashes on startup after splash screen

fields.description:
While trying to look for the typo mentioned below I saw that there is another typo in the create patch dialog: "File alread exist. "

[Screenshot with typo|https://imgur.com/a/t492zCQ]

A second typo marked in Transifex is with the ressource RestDataErrorAdvice:
"Please check you user credentials." --> "Please check your user credentials."
https://www.transifex.com/atlassian/sourcetree-for-windows/translate/#de/Messages/109278795

Also the translation at transifex seems to contain a typo in the original sources.
The resource is labelled CreatingPathTitle and is listed as "Creating pacth"
https://www.transifex.com/atlassian/sourcetree-for-windows/translate/#de/Messages/139896138
I could not find the title in any dialog when creating patches ... so this might have already been resolved ... but maybe the translation sources could be updated as well.
fields.summary: Typo file already exists in creating patch dialog. Translation for CreatingPathTitle and RestDataErrorAdvice

fields.description:
Just updated SourceTree, and I have several issues with it (you can split this into multiple JIRAs if you want).

After the update and restart (twice, to see if the message would go away) I get this message:

Git-LFS not supported.
 You'll need to upgrade to Git 2.12.1 or later.
 We recommend upgrading to Git 2.17.1.2.
 # So first issue - if updating SourceTree is going to *require* updating to a new version of Git, I should be warned about that before accepting the update. The way it is working now, updating SourceTree with a single click would leave me unable to work without updating Git (which takes quite a bit more work than a single click).
 # Second issue. The message says to update to at least Git 2.12.1, and recommends 2.17.1.2. I currently have Git 2.17.1.windows.1. So I meet the requirement. Why am I being prompted?
 # Third issue - I don't even use Git LFS! I'd never even heard of it before getting this message! I DO use Git Flow, but I'm not getting messages about that (which I shouldn't, since my Git version is recent enough). But Git LFS is not something I use.
fields.summary: Version 2.6.6.0 Reports Git-LFS not supported erroneously

fields.description: I attempted to close a feature branch. I added the tag that included an ampersand (CNT-421&CNTUI-123). The tag that was applied to the branch was CNT-421 as the ampersand was not escaped when running the command in Git. The ampersand was treated the same as an ampersand in Bash, which allows the command to run in the background. There is a possible security hole here as well as it may be possible to inject bash scripting after the ampersand since the shell being used to run the command may return to a usable shell after the ampersand is processed. The ampersand (and probably other characters) needs to be properly escaped when included in the tag of a branch closure.
fields.summary: Linux Git Server - Ampersand (&) in tag is not properly handled when closing a branch

fields.description:
After upgrading to 2.6.6, password prompts keep appearing and doesn't appear to cache the credentials, even after successful login.

There is no indication which account or repository it is trying to authenticate to, the title bar doesn't give you the information

The login is for VSTS, and associated with the Git Saved Passwords.

Using embedded git version 2.17.1/LibGit2Sharp 0.24.0 + git-lfs v2.4.2.

The selected SSH client is PuTTY/Plink
fields.summary: Authentication prompts keep popping up

fields.description: The version check does not handle Git for Windows version string 2.17.1.windows.2 and is permanently displaying the required upgrade hint.
fields.summary: Git-LFS Version check does not consider windows version string

fields.description: When I install SourceTree 2.5.5 and change the installation path to my Windows C drive instead of my user profile, is it not listed in the programs menu after installation is completed. So the user has no way to launch after installation. Same thing happens when I install SourceTree Enterprise MSI version and change the installation path to Windows C drive.
fields.summary: SourceTree not showing up in Windows program menu

fields.description:
When using GitFlow, if you have a Release branch active, and a Hotfix branch active, and you finish you Hotfix branch, changes are merged to the Master and the Develop branches - but they should be merged into Master and Release branches.

 

see [https://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/] 

??The one exception to the rule here is that, *when a release branch currently exists, the hotfix changes need to be merged into that release branch, instead of {{develop}}*.??
fields.summary: GitFlow finish Hotfix when release branch is active

fields.description:
After updating to the new SourceTree 2.6.6 version, the credential manager settings in the global .gitconfig file is ignored. Since we are using AWS, the credential manager is not wanted and the global git config is configured as such. However, SourceTree (since the update to 2.6.6) still opens the embedded credential manager (AppData ... git_extras).

SourceTree is also configured to use the system provided git, not the embedded version.

Git changes via the command prompt works as before without issued (the GCM is not opened / used).

SourceTree does seem to load the global git config file as the file is "touched" on each SourceTree boot.

Because SourceTree wants to use GCM regardless of config setting, AWS git repositories can no longer be managed.

There are no credential manager settings set for git configuration on "local" or "system" level.

 

Downgrade to 2.5.5 fixes the issue
fields.summary: Global git settings ignored by source tree after update

fields.description:
When selecting a folder to commit, right click, select ignore. If the folder contains many files, they all gets listed and the options goes so far down and out of the window, so you can't select any option.

i can send you a screenshot if you want.

can be reproduced many times
fields.summary: Ignore display gets out of the window and can't be used

fields.description:
# I type some commit message
 # Do some work with code
 # Update commit message in SourceTree editor
 # Go away from SourceTree window
 # Switch to SourceTree and see how my message replaced with first version

Autorefresh on file changes is disable (and no file changes was made by me).
fields.summary: Text in "File status" editor resetted

fields.description:
Hi,

 

After upgraded to v2.6.6, my SourceTree is now broken when I perform Pull and getting the error logs below. I've been using username contain space in between, e.g. "Jhessie Johnson".

The sourcetree is now unusable and cannot proceed with any Git actions. 

 

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false --no-optional-locks -c credential.helper= -c "credential.helper=C:/Users/Jhessie Johnson/AppData/Local/Atlassian/SourceTree/git_extras/git-credential-manager.exe" fetch origin
C:/Users/Jhessie Johnson/AppData/Local/Atlassian/SourceTree/git_extras/git-credential-manager.exe get: C:/Users/Jhessie: No such file or directory
C:/Users/Jhessie Johnson/AppData/Local/Atlassian/SourceTree/git_extras/git-credential-manager.exe erase: C:/Users/Jhessie: No such file or directory
fatal: Authentication failed for 'https://mycompany.visualstudio.com/Interaction/_git/--Init/'
fields.summary: SourceTree Critical Issue

fields.description:
Just updated from SourceTree 2.5.5 to SourceTree 2.6.6.  After startup, SourceTree shows yellow flag that says "A newer version of Git-LFS is available"

I check in my SourceTree installation folder, and see two different git-lfs.exe exists.

One is v2.0.2, which is the one SourceTree is detecting.  The other is v2.4.2, which is not being detected.

For some reason, the update to SourceTree v2.6.6 didn't properly cleanup the older git-lfs.exe

New version was in C:\Users\<my user name>\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\git_local\mingw32\bin\

Old version was in C:\Users\<my user name>\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\git_local\mingw32\libexec\git-core\

All the other files in the same directory as the old version all seemd to be current, e.g. git-*.exe files from embedded Git were all for version v2.7.1.2 (the current version)

To me it seems like something has changed with the placement of git-lfs.exe, and the updater is not cleaning out the old git-lfs.exe when it runs.
fields.summary: Sourcetree flags Git-LFS as outdated, even though current version installed
git-credential-manager.exe path with whitespace character

fields.description:
I use SourceTree with remote Windows network shares that come and go with regular use. Every time nearly any interaction is done on the UI, SourceTree decides to go lookup some data from the network shares. This, in my use case, always has a 30-90 second timeout that prevents any UI updates. Windows even thinks the program has crashed usually and I must select "Wait for application to finish". Once accessing the file actually times out, the UI usually becomes responsive again for a little bit until it decides to go and check missing network shares again.

This makes me think the thread that does the UI drawing also does the filesystem interaction which means if the filesystem is slow, the UI is slow.

I believe is is the inaccessible network shares that are causing this issue because I can see large pauses in Sourcetree's activity in Sysinternals' Procmon. I have felt the "slowness" that many many other users have reported before I started using network shares. This is different. The UI unresponsiveness for 30+ seconds only started after using network shares.
fields.summary: UI Locks up when SourceTree updates repositories
source is exiting

fields.description:
Please create tool tips / "hints" for all the user interfaces in standalone Sourcetree for Windows.   

As it is right now, there are many things to click on and check and tweak where the meaning can only be guessed at by the end user.   This results in a lot of mistakes, frustration, and fear in new and even more experienced users, as users are left to only guess at what various tools and options actually do.

This seems like a super easy and low-risk change to make, that can vastly improve the experience for many of us.

_PS: I hope this is the right spot to make suggestions - I'm just guessing based on the links from your support site.   It sort of feels like I should not be here :)_
fields.summary: Add tool tips "hints" for all Sourcetree user interface elements

fields.description:
Before using the SourceTree Options dialog, my .gitconfig proxy settings look like this:
{code:java}
[http]
proxy = http://not.my.real.proxy.net:8888
[https]
proxy = http://not.my.real.proxy.net:8888
{code}
 
 After opening the options dialog and closing, it either using the OK button or the close button in the title bar, my .gitconfig proxy settings look like this:
{code:java}
[http]
[https]
proxy = http://not.my.real.proxy.net:8888
{code}
This breaks Git operations that use the network for me.
fields.summary: HTTP proxy settings is being deleted

fields.description:
I often use staging by patch. Unfortunately this fails if the patch contains umlauts. Maybe this happens for Unicode/UTF8 in general.

There is a message box which says something like (using german UI):

git apply failed with code 1: Checking patch ... error: while searching for:

... here comes the patch ...

error: patch failed

error: patch does not apply

See (%LocalAppData%\) Atlassian\SourceTree\LastFailedPatch.txt for patch details.

 

It's not critical, but rather annoying.
fields.summary: Staging by patch fails if block contains umlauts

fields.description:
I went to the sourcetree homepage and wanted to download the Windows version.

 

There were two options (This is in german but here I wrote english): 

Download for Mac OSX     

(and below that) Also available for Mac OSX

 

I was a bit confused and pressed on the upper one, which was correct for Windows.
fields.summary: The german text for 'Download for Windows' says Mac OS X instead

fields.description:
Given the number of repositories I use at any given time, I find myself needing to recreate the same group of "Commit text links" for each repo. 

It would be a great time-saver if it were possible to specify a set of "Commit text links" that could be application-wide (per-user), or specific to a known remote host, or a combination of the two with an inheritance of values from the previous level(s).
fields.summary: Create default set of "Commit text links"

fields.description: When cloning a repository from a BitBucket (cloud or hosted) server, it would be extremely useful and time-saving if the `Optional extended integration` values could be automatically populated. This could probably be determined either by a) a header (HTTP) returned from the server when cloning, b) looking up the host name against the entries in the "Authentication" preference tab (if any), asking at the time that the clone operation is requested
fields.summary: Automatically set extended integration information for BitBucket/Stash backed repositories

fields.description: Requirement : Atlassian Source tree sould be able to push and pull into Bitbucket Repository via OpenID (Authentication and authorization).
fields.summary: Open ID Authentication and Authorization
Tabs order is reset on each start

fields.description: On attempting to create a Git Flow branch from the working copy, I get an error message claiming I'm not on a branch. However, the working copy is on a branch (a local branch). This worked fine before, and appears to be a regression in either 2.6.3 or perhaps the previous version (2.5.5?).
fields.summary: Git Flow "Start New Feature" does not allow branching from working copy

fields.description:
Tags with spaces are supported by mercurial, but not by sourcetree. For example command *hg tag "Some tag"* is valid, but I can't do the same in sourcetree as seen in this screenshot:

!image-2018-06-07-11-41-54-831.png!
fields.summary: Can't add tag containing spaces for mercurial repo

fields.description:
Every time I focus the SourceTree application; it shows a "nice" notification about a newer version of Git-LFS.
I use my local (system) git, not the embedded variant and we don't use Git-LFS.
Thus my request: Add a check-box if you're using Git-LFS and when this is disabled; don't show any notifications.
fields.summary: Disable annoying Git-LFS notification

fields.description:
Git command line provides a feature to merge a branch into another branch without creating auto-commit (even in case of no conflicts). There should be that option available in SourceTree as well.

_git merge --no-commit_
fields.summary: Option for Git Merge Without Auto-Commit
Allow Ctrl-F or similar find feature for text in the commit output window

fields.description:
Our users authenticate with our Bitbucket server using the company's LDAP/Active Directory. After a password change, any authenticated Git operations (pull/push/fetch) will fail due to authentication error.

Logging into Bitbucket via browser works as expected with the updated credentials. Refreshing the account password via SourceTree UI (Tools>Options>Accounts) shows as succeeded, but does not resolve authentication error.

The only fairly reliable workaround we've found is to remove the "passwd" file located at "C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree", restarting SourceTree, and then re-doing the operation. While this typically works, I can't imagine it's the intended procedure and can be difficult to remember how to do for users that only encounter the issue every few months.
fields.summary: Password change prevents authenticated operations (push/pull/fetch) without manual workaround

fields.description:
# Created a fork on GitHub
 # Cloned that fork into a repository in SourceTree
 # Note that this fork inherits the same branches as its parent had (e.g. "master").
 # Go to repository settings to add its parent fork as an additional remote, called this "upstream".
 # In the left hand column, checkout upstream's "master" branch to be included in my local branches.
 # Note that I can't call the local version "master" because my fork already has a branch by this name. Will call it "upstream_master" for this demonstration.
 # Later I want to push changes to this branch, so I right click the branch and choose "Push to upstream/master (tracked)".
 # *This is where the problem occurs:* in the Push dialog that comes up, it will have "upstream" selected at the top for "Push to repository", but the actual name it will give for the branch is "upstream_master". This means when I click push, it will end up creating a new branch on the upstream repository called "upstream_master" rather than pushing to the "master" branch it was checked out from.

I seem to be able to work around this by changing the name of the branch in the dialog every time I push this way, but it does not appear to remember where it should push. I have to remember to do this every time, and if I fail to do this I end up making a mess with a new branch.

I also notice that when using the Commit feature the "Push changes immediately to" checkbox will never suggest the remote branch to push to (just displays "-" permanently).

For branches that go to the fork that the repository was originally created with, I can rename them and they still remember which remote branch they were attached to.
fields.summary: Branch name for second remote push incorrect

fields.description:
Some wrong translations are found in the Japanese GUI.
Japanese UI shows the options for Mercurial even though it's a label inside the GUI setting. This is causing confusion for users using the Japanese GUI.
* Menu: Option -> Git
||Source||Current Target||Suggested Target||
|Embedded|内蔵 Mercurial を使用|内蔵 Git を使用|
|Update Embedded|内蔵 Mercurial を更新|内蔵 Git を更新|
|System|システム Mercurial を使用|システム Git を使用|

Please see the attached screenshots for the actual GUI.
fields.summary: Wrong Japanese translation in the UI

fields.description:
After trying to authenticate I receive "Something went wrong while attempting to validate your credentials" message. I can login to Atlassian.com just fine. I even reset my password. Still nothing... 

 

Now here's whats funny. I can put a bogus ID/PWD and hit Log in, Same results!!! 

One issue reported adding "AllowModifyConfigFIles" Value: True to the user.config file which I did and still having the same problem. 

I've tried installing SourceTree 2.1.11.0 and 2.3.5.0 and have the exact same issue. 

 

Please assist
fields.summary: Something went wrong while attempting to validate your credentials

fields.description: When stashing changes allow the user to stipulate that untracked files should be included in the stash via the --all option
fields.summary: Add --all option on stash changes in Git

fields.description:
The SourceTree download archive is not up to date.

[https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/download-archives]

fields.description:
h2. *Issue description*

I installed SourceTree Enterprise and attempted to login to my local Bitbucket Server installation. The login fails with the message "failed to check login for user [{username}]".

The log has the following entries:
ERROR [timestamp] [1] [SourceTree.Exceptions.RemoteHostException] [.ctor] - Insufficient authentication credentials
ERROR [timestamp] [1] [SourceTree.Exceptions.RemoteHostException] [.ctor] - Failed to check login for user [{username}]

The root URL ( "https://\{server\}.\{domain\}/\{context\}/" ), username and password are the same ones I use when successfully logging into Bitbucket in Internet Explorer on the same PC.

My username does not include any special characters such as the '@' symbol.

I have tried the suggestions in the following:
https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/Getting-this-error-quot-Something-went-wrong-while-attempting-to/qaq-p/805220
https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/Looking-for-more-details-on-login-error/qaq-p/802237

What additional authentication credentials should be supplied, and how?

It seems rather over the top to raise a bug when I suspect all I'm missing is some documentation on how to set SourceTree up correctly, but I can't seem to find anything and the community question I raised hasn't received any responses (https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/SourceTree-Enterprise-quot-failed-to-check-login-for-user-quot/qaq-p/810106).

h2. *Cause*

As of Sourcetree for Windows v2.5.5, it appears that the login to local Bitbucket Server instance will fail with "failed to check login for user [{username}]" when Bitbucket Server is on a context path (e.g. https://internal.mysite.com/bitbucket).

h2. *Work around*

# Use Sourcetree for Windows v2.4.8.0; or
# Temporarily drop the context path by changing the Base URL of Bitbucket to say just https://internal.mysite.com. e.g.
#* Update reverse proxy *from* "/bitbucket" -> http://<bitbucketserver>:<port>/bitbucket *to* "/" -> http://<bitbucketserver>:<port>/
#* Deleted the {{server.context-path}} line out of bitbucket.properties
#* Updated the Bitbucket Administration » Base URL to just https://internal.mysite.com
#* Restart Bitbucket
#* Perform the login into Sourcetree and hopefully it succeeds this time
#* Once all the users have installed Sourcetree, you can revert Bitbucket back to the Context Path /bitbucket
#* Now that you are in Sourcetree, you should be able to Clone a REPO from https://internal.mysite.com/bitbucket and do all things branch, commit, push, pull, etc...
fields.summary: SourceTree Enterprise: "failed to check login for user"

fields.description:
OpenSSH client is enabled by default in the 1803 update. It can store the private keys within a Windows security context, and start *ssh-agent* service as default agent. Like macOS, it won't ask for input phrase next time, even after reboot.

To make git using  default OpenSSH client, add following lines to *.gitconfig*:

{code}
[core]
  sshCommand = \"C:/Windows/System32/OpenSSH/ssh.exe\"
{code}

Sourcetree still using the bundled OpenSSH as default ssh client, even if *.gitconfig* is configured. Sourcetree can get this feature by reading default *.gitconfig* before launch ssh.

FYI
- http://adamralph.com/2018/05/15/windows-10-version-1803-broke-my-git-ssh/
- https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/powershell/2017/12/15/using-the-openssh-beta-in-windows-10-fall-creators-update-and-windows-server-1709/
fields.summary: In Windows 10 Fall Creators Update, using default OpenSSH client but not the bundled one
Add 'no-commit' option to "Reverse commit..."

fields.description:
Trying to register as part of the install - when change the IE security settings and broweremulation (see below)

Get error something went wrong while attempting to validate your credentials

*I have 2FA on - is this causing it?*

 

 

 

 

 

After some investigation it would sem that you need to have the following settings for IE 10 (I suspect IE11 will be similar)

*Workaround*

At a minimum IE needs to be configured as follows:

Cog/Internet options/Security settings need to be enabled
 * Misc/Access data sources across domains
 * Misc/Allow META-REFRESH
 * Scripting/Active Scripting

 
 * The browser mode set to 10
 * The document mode set to 10

These can be set using the F12 developer tools.

Those are the settings that matter. It should also be able to set them indirectly by:
 * making sure [https://id.atlassian.com|https://id.atlassian.com/] is NOT set to be rendered in Compatibility Mode
 * Set Cog/Internet options/Security to Medium-High
fields.summary: Can't Install Source Tree - won't login on W2012

fields.description:
EDIT: This probably is about the newline chracters used: The offending lines are separated by just CR instead of CRLF, in other places in the file there is a CR&LF used - As "only" CR is also a valid newline character it is still a bug, imo.  btw: Bitbucket displays the solo CR as a special character in the same line, and does not do a newline, so that is inconsistent with ST, too.

 

ORIGINAL POST

I overwrote a .tex file with another version of it. The version on disk is now exactly as i want it. Sourcetree is showing the file as altered, but not all alterations are shown, and some nonexistent alterations are shown. Additionally the line-numbering is off.

See attached Screenshot: (yellow highlighted regions)

I opened the file in Notepad++ to show the real content, and you can see in the background the Sourcetree diff, with wrong line numbering (observe that the real /begin->/end block is four lines from 40 to 43 and the Sourcetree diff is a weird /begin->/end/end block) and, very importantly: *A line that does not exist anymore (Sourcetree line 36) is not marked as missing!*

I tried commiting, the commit works with the real file, and also reverts fine, but the shown diff is always wrong. Altering stuff in N++ and saving resulted in a still wrong diff, that some times showed a +/- of lines that were unaltered and mostly showed the altered line (i experimented with the Windows 8 line ) as unaltered.

A diff using the diff tool from TortoiseGit was normal and correct.

Just to be clear: I doublechecked that N++ and Sourcetree are seeing the same file, by altering it in N++ and seeing the file change in Sourcetree - so this is not about looking at different files, this is some bug(?) in the ST-Diff (not the actual storing of files, just the showing of the differences)

In Bitbucket, the file is shown in a way that makes me think this is about encoding: See attached screenshot: "Line 33" in reality is four lines (and shows, if copy pasted into N++, as four lines), but some weird special characters are shown at the linebreak. (See Screenshot of old version of the file, with "Windows 8"-line still in)
fields.summary: Sourcetree diff view omits deletions and has wrong line numbering

I tried login with different Source tree versions and resetting my password but still getting same error 'Something went wrong while attempting to validate your credentials.'

fields.description:
I rename a file in Visual Studio without changing the file content then I use "Add/Remove" action in Sourcetree. 

*Actual behavior*

The file's icon in Pending changes is the rename icon. But when click on the file to see the changes, SourceTree show two time the file's content. The first one is all red (removed) and the second one is all green (added) (see attachment).

Then after the commit, there are remaining changes that are a remove of the renamed files.

*Expected behavior*

The file's icon in Pending changes is the rename icon. When I see what change in the file, I see "no changes" or only the lines that actually changes.

 

This cause a lot of problem with ours reviews because it's very hard to what actually change in these files.
fields.summary: Sourcetree git fail to rename file

fields.description:
Prior to experiencing this issue, install sourcetree using Bitbucket cloud credentials.

When Jira is set to use our AD user principle name, which is our email address (of the format firstname.lastname@pncc.govt.nz):
 * Click to get a new tab.
 * Select Remote
 * Add an account
 ** Hosting service: Bitbucket server; url: [http://bitbucket.pncc.govt.nz:7990;|http://bitbucket.pncc.govt.nz:7990,/] protocol: https; auth: basic; username: (style [of firstname.lastname@pncc.govt.nz)|mailto:of%C2%A0first.last@pncc.govt.nz]
 ** Click refresh password

The response message in the Edit Hosting Account dialog indicates it is hitting the rest api for [http://bitbucket.pncc.govt.nz:7990|http://bitbucket.pncc.govt.nz:7990,/]/rest/api/1.0/users/firstname.lastname%40pncc.govt.nz, but the url that works is the one using the slug, which is [http://bitbucket.pncc.govt.nz:7990|http://bitbucket.pncc.govt.nz:7990,/]/rest/api/1.0/users/firstname.lastname_pncc.govt.nz - but if I use the slug (firstname.lastname_pncc.govt.nz) as the username in the dialog, I get an "unauthorized" error. This fault affects all users, not just myself.

 

When we change Jira to use a different property in AD to authenticate against, eg any one without an "@" in it such as the samaccountname, and attempt the same action, the result is as expected - we get to see the list of remote repos.

 

In either case, if we browse to a repo page on our Bitbucket server and click Clone, sourcetree will work as expected.

 

Initially logged on the product questions board, [here|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/Add-account-for-remote-repo-where-usernames-have-character/qaq-p/784118].
fields.summary: Add account for remote repo where usernames have '@' character

fields.description:
Issue SRCTREEWIN-1504 was closed in 2016 because of some kind of issue cleanup.

But it is still an issue in the current Sourcetree for Windows.  You have to select 1 or more explicit branches to push (such as master) before the push dialog lets you proceed, and then it will invoke git push with explicit refspecs like "git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false push -v origin master:master".

We have multiple refspecs configured for origin in order to have branch commits and notes pushed together:

jdoyle@TS MINGW64 ~/git/smsmis (master)
$ git config --get-regexp remote.origin.push
remote.origin.push HEAD
remote.origin.push refs/notes/cr
remote.origin.push refs/notes/sourceCommits
remote.origin.push refs/notes/releaseMerge
remote.origin.push refs/notes/releaseRollback
remote.origin.push refs/notes/releaseCopy 

But this configuration only takes effect if you "git push" without explicit command line refspecs, and therefore doesn't take effect from the Sourcetree push dialog.

As noted in the original issue, you can create a custom action to do a "git push" without explicit refspecs, but it would be a lot clearer if the actual "Push" button and push dialog did this.
fields.summary: Push refspec not honored

fields.summary: Hide or disable "Custom Actions" menu item

fields.description:
At the moment it is not possible to synchronize local and remote tags within SourceTree. This leads to the following problem scenario:

 
 # User A locally deletes a tag and pushes the changes to the remote (Tag -> Remove Tag -> Remove tag from all remotes). The tag gets removed from the remote repository.
 # User B sees no changes in SourceTree, but does a pull anyway. User B locally still sees the tag although it was removed in the remote repository.
 # User B then commits and pushes some code changes and has the "Push all tags" option selected.
 # The removed tag now exists in the remote branch again.

 

We have experienced this problem in our team frequently. Removed tags kept reappearing, until we realized what was going on.

Please add functionality for synchronizing tags between local and remote repositories or an option to remove tags that do no longer exist in the remote repository. Something analogous to the "Prune tracking branches no longer present on remote(s)" option in the Fetch dialog.
fields.summary: Add functionality for synchronizing local/remote tags

fields.description:
Hi,

I just changed my password, but now i'm not be able to access using the sourcetree desktop application
fields.summary: Login fails after password change

fields.description: External diffs have worked well for me for the previous year, but a recent update broke the paths. I adjusted the script to match the new format for the file status tab, only to find that the external diff launched from the log window doesn't pass parameters the same way.
fields.summary: External diff parameters aren't passing paths consistently.

fields.description:
Now that the order of open tabs is again saved in Sourctree 2.6.0.0-beta0 I noticed that although the order is now saved the last active tab is still the one before the move.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open at least 2 repositories in different tabs
    [Repo 1] [Repo 2] [Repo 3 (active)]
2. Move/Drag the last active tab with the mouse to position 2
    [Repo 1] [Repo 3 (active)] [Repo 2]
3. Close Sourcetree and open Sourcetree again

Expected:

1. The second tab is active as before closing Sourcetree
    [Repo 1] [Repo 3 (active)] [Repo 2]

Actual:

1. The third tab is active as before the tab move/drag
    [Repo 1] [Repo 3] [Repo 2 (active)]


Minor issue because typically you do not move/drag around repositories a lot and the overall order of tabs and repositories is still saved.
fields.summary: Last active tab not saved if the tab was moved before closing the application
